entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Logistics with Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)
entry.content:
The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Logistics with Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)

A Practical Handbook for End Users, Key Users, and Consultants

Foreword

Welcome to the comprehensive guide for mastering SAP S/4HANA Logistics, with a core focus on Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). In today's fast-paced business environment, efficient logistics and warehouse operations are not just a necessity but a critical competitive advantage. SAP S/4HANA, with its powerful in-memory database and streamlined processes, offers an unparalleled platform to achieve this efficiency.

This guide is designed for a wide audience, from end-users performing daily tasks and beginners seeking to understand the fundamentals, to key users and consultants responsible for implementation and optimization. We will embark on a journey starting from high-level business planning, drilling down into the intricacies of master data, and executing end-to-end logistics processes within a realistic business context.

Our case study will be CycleCorp, a modern bicycle manufacturing company that leverages the full power of S/4HANA to manage its supply chain‚Äîfrom procuring components and manufacturing bicycles to delivering the final product to the customer.

This document transforms legacy SAP ECC concepts into the new S/4HANA reality, emphasizing the use of modern SAP Fiori applications for a simplified and intuitive user experience. We will cover the seamless integration between EWM and other core modules like Materials Management (MM), Production Planning (PP), Sales and Distribution (SD), and Quality Management (QM), extending all the way to the financial postings that are the lifeblood of any enterprise.

Finally, this guide includes a detailed, hands-on test plan, allowing you to practice and validate your knowledge through realistic, end-to-end business scenarios.

Let's begin the journey to unlock the full potential of your S/4HANA logistics landscape.

Table of Contents

  1. Chapter 1: Foundations of S/4HANA Logistics & Organizational Structure
    • 1.1. From Business Planning to Logistics Execution
    • 1.2. The Evolution of Warehouse Management: IM, WM, and EWM
    • 1.3. Organizational Structure: Building the Enterprise in SAP
    • 1.4. Customizing Your Organizational Structure
  2. Chapter 2: Master Data - The Digital Blueprint of Your Supply Chain
    • 2.1. The Business Partner (BP) Approach
    • 2.2. The Product Master: More Than Just a Material
    • 2.3. EWM-Specific Master Data: The Key to Warehouse Automation
  3. Chapter 3: Core EWM Processes: The Flow of Goods
    • 3.1. The Inbound Process: From Purchase Order to Putaway
    • 3.2. The Outbound Process: From Sales Order to Goods Issue
    • 3.3. Internal Warehouse Processes & Physical Inventory
  4. Chapter 4: Advanced Production Integration: Kanban with EWM
    • 4.1. Kanban Principles in a Modern S/4HANA Landscape
    • 4.2. Kanban Master Data: The Control Cycle
    • 4.3. Scenario A: External Procurement Kanban
    • 4.4. Scenario B: In-House Production Kanban
    • 4.5. Scenario C: EWM Stock Transfer Kanban for Production Supply
  5. Chapter 5: Integrated Test Plan: A Hands-On Workshop
    • 5.1. Introduction to the Test Plan
    • 5.2. Test Scenario 1: Procure-to-Pay (Component Inbound)
    • 5.3. Test Scenario 2: Order-to-Cash (Finished Bicycle Outbound)
    • 5.4. Test Scenario 3: EWM Kanban Stock Transfer to Production
  6. Appendix
    • A.1: Glossary of Key Terms
    • A.2: Fiori App and GUI Transaction Code Map

Chapter 1: Foundations of S/4HANA Logistics & Organizational Structure

Before we can receive, store, or ship goods, we must first build the foundational structure of our company in SAP and understand the business logic that drives our processes.

1.1. From Business Planning to Logistics Execution

Every action in the warehouse is the result of a higher-level plan. At CycleCorp, the production of bicycles is not random; it follows a structured planning hierarchy that ensures the company meets market demand while optimizing resources.

  • Strategic Level - Sales and Operations Planning (S&OP) / Plan Industriel et Commercial (PIC): This is the long-term view (typically 1-2 years), where executive management aligns sales forecasts with production, inventory, and financial goals. For CycleCorp, this means deciding how many total bicycles (by family, e.g., "Mountain Bikes," "Road Bikes") to produce each quarter to meet annual targets. This process is supported by SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) in modern landscapes.
  • Tactical Level - Demand Management & Master Production Scheduling (MPS) / Programme Directeur de Production (PDP): This phase breaks down the S&OP into a more detailed plan at the individual product level (e.g., how many "Model X Mountain Bikes" to produce each month). It considers actual customer orders and forecasts over a medium-term horizon (3-6 months).
  • Operational Level - Material Requirements Planning (MRP): This is the engine that explodes the Master Production Schedule. MRP calculates the precise quantities and timings for all components and raw materials needed to build the bicycles. If the PDP demands 1,000 Model X bikes, MRP will calculate the need for 2,000 wheels, 1,000 frames, 1,000 saddles, etc., and generate procurement proposals (Purchase Requisitions) or production proposals (Planned Orders). In S/4HANA, this is executed via MRP Live (MD01N), which leverages the speed of HANA for real-time planning.
  • Execution Level - Warehouse & Production Floor: The proposals generated by MRP trigger the actual execution processes:
    • Purchase Requisitions are converted to Purchase Orders, which initiates the EWM inbound process.
    • Planned Orders are converted to Production Orders, which triggers material staging from the EWM warehouse to the production line.

1.2. The Evolution of Warehouse Management: IM, WM, and EWM

SAP has offered several levels of warehouse management over the years. Understanding their differences is key to appreciating the power of S/4HANA EWM.

  • Inventory Management (IM): This is the most basic level. Stock is managed at the Storage Location level. You know you have 100 wheels in Storage Location 0001, but you don't know where within that storage location they are. It's like knowing a book is in a library but not which shelf it's on. IM is suitable for very small, simple warehouses.
  • Warehouse Management (WM): The legacy solution, which is being phased out in S/4HANA (ending support in 2027). WM introduced the concept of the Storage Bin. Now you know you have 100 wheels in Storage Location 0001, specifically in bin A-01-02. This allows for directed movements and better space management.
  • Extended Warehouse Management (EWM): The strategic, state-of-the-art warehouse solution for S/4HANA. EWM is a far more advanced and flexible system built from the ground up to handle complex logistics operations. It can be run as Embedded EWM (within the same S/4HANA system, recommended for most cases) or Decentralized EWM (on a separate server, for very high-volume warehouses).

Key Advantages of EWM over legacy WM:

Feature

Legacy WM

S/4HANA EWM

Business Benefit for CycleCorp

Warehouse Structure

Rigid structure (Warehouse > Storage Type > Bin)

Highly flexible (Activity Areas, Work Centers, Sections)

Better organization of the warehouse for different tasks like receiving, picking, and packing.

Process Control

Limited process control

Process-Oriented Storage Control (POSC) & Layout-Oriented Storage Control (LOSC)

Can model complex multi-step processes, like receiving a pallet, moving it to a deconsolidation station, then putting away individual cases.

Monitoring

Basic List Displays (e.g., LL01)

Warehouse Monitor (/SCWM/MON) & Fiori Apps

A powerful, all-in-one tool for real-time visibility and management of all warehouse resources and documents.

Optimization

Basic picking/putaway strategies

Advanced algorithms for slotting, labor management, wave picking, and replenishment.

Ensures that fast-moving items are placed in easily accessible bins and that picker travel paths are optimized, saving time and money.

Value-Added Services (VAS)

Very limited

Integrated VAS capabilities for kitting, labeling, special packing.

CycleCorp can easily manage the creation of "bike kits" (e.g., a bike plus a helmet and water bottle) directly in the warehouse.

Quality Management

Basic integration

Seamless, advanced integration with QM for creating inspections, managing samples, and stock posting.

Automatically triggers a quality check on incoming high-end carbon frames before they are put away.

1.3. Organizational Structure: Building the Enterprise in SAP

The organizational structure is the digital skeleton of CycleCorp. Each element has a specific legal or business purpose.

Key Organizational Units:

  • Company Code (e.g., 2222 - CycleCorp US): An independent legal and accounting entity. A company code is the level at which financial statements like balance sheets and profit & loss statements are generated.
  • Plant (e.g., 2222 - CycleCorp Dallas Plant): An operational unit within a company. A plant can be a manufacturing facility, a distribution center, or a corporate office. It is a central entity for production, procurement, and planning.
  • Storage Location (e.g., 2222 - Raw Materials): A subdivision of a Plant where stock is physically stored and managed on a quantity basis (IM level). A Plant can have multiple Storage Locations.
  • Purchasing Organization (e.g., 2222 - CycleCorp US Purchasing): The organizational unit responsible for procuring materials and services and negotiating purchasing conditions with suppliers.
  • Warehouse Number (e.g., W22 - CycleCorp Dallas EWM Warehouse): The highest-level organizational unit in EWM. It represents an entire physical warehouse complex. A warehouse number is assigned to a combination of a Plant and Storage Location.
  • Storage Type (e.g., 001 - High Rack Storage): A physical or logical subdivision of a warehouse, defined by its characteristics. Examples include high-rack storage, bulk storage, goods receipt area, or production supply area.
  • Storage Bin (e.g., H01-01-A): The smallest addressable unit of space in a warehouse where products are stored.

1.4. Customizing Your Organizational Structure

Setting up the organizational structure is a foundational activity performed by consultants using the SAP Implementation Guide (IMG).

SPRO Menu Path: SAP Reference IMG (Transaction: SPRO) -> Enterprise Structure -> Definition / Assignment

Step-by-Step Customizing Example:

  1. Define Company Code (SPRO):
    • Path: Definition -> Financial Accounting -> Edit, Copy, Delete, Check Company Code
    • Create 2222 for "CycleCorp US".
  2. Define Plant (SPRO):
    • Path: Definition -> Logistics - General -> Define, copy, delete, check Plant
    • Create 2222 for "CycleCorp Dallas Plant" and assign it to Company Code 2222.
  3. Define Storage Location (SPRO):
    • Path: Definition -> Materials Management -> Maintain storage location
    • For Plant 2222, create:
      • 2222: Raw Materials (for general components)
      • 2223: EWM Managed Raw Materials (this specific SLoc will be linked to EWM)
      • 2224: Production Supply
  4. Define Warehouse Number (SPRO):
    • Path: SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Master Data -> Define Warehouse Number
    • Create Warehouse W22 for "Dallas EWM Warehouse".
  5. Assign Warehouse Number to Plant/Storage Location (SPRO):
    • Path: Enterprise Structure -> Assignment -> Logistics Execution -> Assign warehouse number to plant/storage location
    • Assign Warehouse W22 to the combination of Plant 2222 and Storage Location 2223. This is the critical link that activates EWM for all stock movements in that storage location.

Chapter 2: Master Data - The Digital Blueprint of Your Supply Chain

Master data is the static, core data that is used across all business transactions. Getting it right is crucial for smooth operations. For CycleCorp, this includes defining our business partners, the products we make and buy, and the warehouse-specific attributes of those products.

2.1. The Business Partner (BP) Approach

In S/4HANA, the separate concepts of "Customer" and "Vendor" have been replaced by a unified Business Partner object. A single BP can have multiple roles.

  • Fiori App: Manage Business Partner Master Data
  • GUI T-Code: BP

Practical Exercise: Creating a Supplier

Let's create one of CycleCorp's key suppliers, "Shimano Components."

  1. Launch the Manage Business Partner Master Data Fiori app.
  2. Click "Create" and select "Organization."
  3. Create in BP Role - General Role (000000):
    • Enter the name: Shimano Components
    • Enter the address details.
    • Save. A BP Number is generated.
  4. Extend to Supplier Role:
    • Open the newly created BP.
    • Click "Edit" and choose to extend the BP to a new role: FLVN01 Supplier.
    • Navigate to the "Purchasing" tab.
    • Enter the Purchasing Organization 2222.
    • Maintain key data like Order Currency (USD), Payment Terms, etc.
    • Save. The BP is now a qualified supplier for CycleCorp.

2.2. The Product Master: More Than Just a Material

The "Material Master" is now called the "Product Master" in S/4HANA. It holds all the information required to manage a product.

  • Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data
  • GUI T-Code: MM01 (Create) / MM02 (Change)

Practical Exercise: Creating a Purchased Component

Let's create the product master for a "Guidon" (handlebar).

  1. Launch the Manage Product Master Data Fiori app and click "Create."
  2. Product Number: DS-GUI01
  3. Product Type: COMP (Component, a type of Raw Material - ROH)
  4. Base Unit of Measure: PC (Piece)
  5. Select the views to create: Basic Data, Purchasing, MRP 1-4, General Plant Data / Storage, Warehouse Management, Accounting.
  6. Key View Data:
    • Purchasing View: Enter Purchasing Group, set "Automatic PO" flag if desired.
    • MRP 1 View:
      • MRP Type: ND (No Planning) for Kanban items, as their replenishment is triggered by the Kanban signal, not MRP. For other items, you might use PD (MRP).
    • MRP 2 View:
      • Procurement Type: F (External Procurement).
      • Production Storage Location: 2224 (where the component will be supplied to the line).
      • Default Supply Area: DS-AIR (the specific area on the production line).
    • General Plant Data / Storage 1: Maintain basic weight and dimension data.
    • Accounting 1 View:
      • Valuation Class: 3000 (Raw Materials). This links the material to the correct G/L accounts in Finance.
      • Price Control: S (Standard Price) or V (Moving Average Price).
  7. Save the product.

2.3. EWM-Specific Master Data: The Key to Warehouse Automation

Once a product is created, it must be extended to the EWM warehouse to enable advanced logistics processes.

  • Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data (Warehouse Views)
  • GUI T-Code: /SCWM/MAT1

Practical Exercise: Extending the Guidon to the EWM Warehouse

  1. Open the DS-GUI01 product in the Manage Product Master Data app.
  2. Navigate to the "Warehouse Management" view section.
  3. Enter the Warehouse Number W22.
  4. Maintain key EWM data on the different tabs:
    • Warehouse Data Tab:
      • Putaway Control Ind.: PC01 (e.g., Standard Putaway). This indicator tells EWM which putaway strategy to use for this product.
      • Stock Removal Cntrl Ind.: RC01 (e.g., FIFO). This tells EWM which picking strategy to use.
    • Slotting Tab: Used for rules that help the system find the optimal storage bin.
    • Storage Type Data Tab: Here you can define specific parameters if the product behaves differently in a specific storage type (e.g., a fixed bin location).
  5. Save the warehouse product view. The product is now ready for all EWM processes.

Chapter 3: Core EWM Processes: The Flow of Goods

With our structure and master data in place, we can now execute the physical and system processes that move goods through the CycleCorp warehouse.

3.1. The Inbound Process: From Purchase Order to Putaway

This process covers receiving purchased components from our supplier, Shimano Components.

Process Flow:

Purchase Order -> Inbound Delivery -> Goods Receipt -> Putaway Warehouse Task -> Task Confirmation -> Stock in Final Bin

Step-by-Step Execution:

  1. Create Purchase Order:
    • Fiori App: Manage Purchase Orders
    • Create a PO for supplier Shimano Components for 100 pcs of product DS-GUI01 to be delivered to Plant 2222 / Storage Location 2223 (our EWM-managed location).
    • Ensure the "Confirmation Control Key" is set to expect an Inbound Delivery.
  2. Create Inbound Delivery:
    • Fiori App: Create Inbound Deliveries
    • This step can be done manually upon receiving an Advanced Shipping Notification (ASN) from the supplier, or automatically via EDI.
    • Reference the Purchase Order to create the Inbound Delivery. This document is replicated from the ERP side of S/4HANA to the EWM side, becoming an "Inbound Delivery Notification" in EWM.
  3. Post Goods Receipt:
    • Fiori App: Post Goods Receipt for Inbound Delivery
    • When the truck arrives at the CycleCorp warehouse, the operator finds the Inbound Delivery.
    • They check the physical quantity against the delivery document and post the Goods Receipt.
    • At this point, the stock is physically in the Goods Receipt area (e.g., Storage Type GR-ZONE) and visible in the system. An automatic financial posting is made, debiting inventory and crediting the GR/IR account.
  4. Create & Confirm Putaway Warehouse Tasks:
    • Fiori App: Process Warehouse Tasks - Putaway
    • The system automatically creates a Warehouse Task (WT) to move the 100 handlebars from the GR zone to their final storage bin.
    • The destination bin is determined by the putaway strategy configured in the system (e.g., next empty bin, fixed bin).
    • A warehouse operator receives the WT on their Radio Frequency (RF) device, scans the product, drives to the destination bin, places the product, and scans the bin to confirm the task.
    • In the desktop app, you can select the task and click "Confirm in Background."
  5. Verify Stock:
    • Fiori App: Display Stock Overview
    • Check the stock for DS-GUI01. You will now see 100 pcs in Storage Location 2223 and, more specifically, in the exact storage bin where it was put away in Warehouse W22.

3.2. The Outbound Process: From Sales Order to Goods Issue

This process covers picking, packing, and shipping a finished bicycle to a customer.

Process Flow:

Sales Order -> Outbound Delivery -> Picking Warehouse Task -> Task Confirmation -> Packing -> Goods Issue -> Stock & Financial Update

Step-by-Step Execution:

  1. Create Sales Order:
    • Fiori App: Create Sales Orders
    • Create a sales order for a customer for 1 pc of a finished bicycle product.
  2. Create Outbound Delivery:
    • Fiori App: Manage Sales Orders
    • The system checks material availability. If stock is available, an Outbound Delivery can be created. This document is replicated to EWM and becomes an "Outbound Delivery Request."
  3. Create Picking Warehouse Tasks:
    • Fiori App: Run Outbound Delivery Orders - Picking
    • In EWM, a warehouse manager releases the Outbound Delivery for picking, often as part of a wave to group multiple orders together for efficiency.
    • The system creates a picking WT based on the stock removal strategy (e.g., FIFO - First In, First Out). The task directs an operator to the specific bin where the bicycle is stored.
  4. Confirm Picking & Pack:
    • The operator confirms the picking WT using their RF device after moving the bicycle from the storage bin to a packing station (Work Center).
    • Fiori App: Pack Outbound Deliveries
    • At the packing station, the operator packs the bicycle into a shipping box, creating a Handling Unit (HU) in the system. They may also add packing materials and print a shipping label.
  5. Post Goods Issue:
    • Fiori App: Post Goods Issue - Outbound Deliveries
    • Once the truck is loaded, the shipping office posts the Goods Issue.
    • This final step relieves the inventory in EWM and MM, and triggers the financial posting (crediting inventory, debiting Cost of Goods Sold). It also signals the SD module that the order is ready for billing.

3.3. Internal Warehouse Processes & Physical Inventory

Beyond inbound and outbound, warehouses are constantly in motion.

  • Replenishment: EWM can automatically create tasks to move stock from a bulk/reserve storage area to a forward picking area when the picking bin's stock level falls below a defined threshold. This ensures pickers always have stock available.
  • Physical Inventory (PI): EWM provides robust tools for ensuring system stock matches physical stock.
    • Fiori App: Manage Physical Inventory Documents
    • The process involves:
      1. Create PI Document: Define which bins or products to count.
      2. Print Count Sheets / Send to RF: Give instructions to the counters.
      3. Enter Count Results: Input the physical counted quantity.
      4. Post Differences: If there is a discrepancy, the system posts the difference, adjusting the book inventory and creating a financial document to account for the gain or loss.

Chapter 4: Advanced Production Integration: Kanban with EWM

Kanban is a lean manufacturing method for implementing a "pull" system. Instead of pushing components to the production line based on a forecast, the production line itself signals when it needs more parts, pulling them from the warehouse or a supplier. S/4HANA provides a powerful, integrated Kanban framework.

4.1. Kanban Principles in a Modern S/4HANA Landscape

The core idea is a visual signal (the "kanban," which can be a card, an empty container, or an electronic signal) that triggers replenishment. When a container of parts at the production line is emptied, the kanban is sent back to the source of supply. This is the trigger.

  • Source of Supply can be:
    • An external supplier (External Procurement).
    • An internal production process (In-house Production).
    • An upstream warehouse storage area (Stock Transfer).

4.2. Kanban Master Data: The Control Cycle

The heart of the Kanban process in SAP is the Kanban Control Cycle. This master data object defines the relationship between the demand source (the production line) and the supply source.

  • Fiori App: Manage Kanban Control Cycles
  • GUI T-Code: PK01 (Create) / PK02 (Change)

Key Control Cycle Parameters:

  • Product & Production Supply Area (PSA): Defines which material is needed at which specific location on the production floor.
  • Number of Kanbans: How many containers are in the loop.
  • Kanban Quantity: The fixed quantity of material in each container.
  • Replenishment Strategy: The most critical setting. It tells the system how to replenish the material when the kanban is set to "Empty."

4.3. Scenario A: External Procurement Kanban

Goal: When a bin of DS-GUI01 (Guidons) is emptied at the production line, automatically generate a Purchase Order to the supplier Shimano Components.

Process Flow:

Kanban set to EMPTY -> Purchase Requisition created -> PR converted to PO -> Supplier delivers -> Goods Receipt in EWM -> Kanban set to FULL

Configuration & Execution:

  1. Customizing (SPRO):
    • Path: Production -> Kanban -> Replenishment Strategies -> Define External Procurement Strategies
    • Ensure a strategy is defined that creates a Purchase Requisition or Purchase Order directly. For this scenario, we use a strategy that generates a PO based on a pre-existing purchasing contract.
  2. Create Contract:
    • Fiori App: Manage Purchase Contracts (ME31K)
    • Create a quantity contract with Shimano for DS-GUI01, specifying price and other terms. This will be the source document for the automatically created POs.
  3. Create Control Cycle:
    • Fiori App: Manage Kanban Control Cycles
    • Product: DS-GUI01
    • PSA: DS-AIR
    • Replenishment Strategy: 0001 (Standard external proc. with PO)
    • On the "External Procurement" tab, enter the contract number created in the previous step.
  4. Execute the Flow:
    • Fiori App: Kanban Board (PK13N or the Fiori equivalent)
    • Find the control cycle for DS-GUI01. The initial status of the kanbans is "FULL".
    • Simulate consumption by selecting a kanban container and setting its status to EMPTY.
    • Check the result: A new Purchase Order will have been automatically created in the background, referencing the contract. You can see the PO number in the kanban details.
    • The rest of the process follows the standard EWM inbound flow described in Chapter 3. Once the goods receipt is posted for the PO, the kanban status is automatically set back to FULL.

4.4. Scenario B: In-House Production Kanban

Goal: When a bin of a semi-finished good (e.g., DS-WHL01, a wheel assembly) is emptied at the final assembly line, automatically trigger a Production Order to the wheel assembly work center.

Process Flow:

Kanban set to EMPTY -> Production Order created -> Production Order confirmed (GR) -> Stock moved via EWM -> Kanban set to FULL

Configuration & Execution:

  1. Customizing (SPRO):
    • Path: Production -> Kanban -> Replenishment Strategies -> Define In-House Production Strategies
    • Define a strategy that creates a Production Order (e.g., 0006).
  2. Create Master Data:
    • Create the product DS-WHL01 as a Semi-finished Good (HALB).
    • Create its Bill of Materials (BOM) (CS01) and a Routing (CA01).
    • Create a Production Version (C223) linking the BOM and Routing.
  3. Create Control Cycle:
    • Fiori App: Manage Kanban Control Cycles
    • Product: DS-WHL01
    • Replenishment Strategy: 0006 (In-house production with Production Order)
    • On the "In-House Production" tab, enter the Production Version.
  4. Execute the Flow:
    • Fiori App: Kanban Board
    • Set a kanban for DS-WHL01 to EMPTY.
    • Check the result: A Production Order is automatically created.
    • The production team executes and confirms the order (CO11N). This confirmation posts a goods receipt of the wheel assembly into an EWM-managed storage location.
    • The kanban status automatically flips to FULL.

4.5. Scenario C: EWM Stock Transfer Kanban for Production Supply

Goal: When a bin of components (e.g., DS-GUI01) at the production line (PSA) runs low, automatically trigger a replenishment task within the EWM warehouse to move more from the bulk reserve area. This is the most common and powerful Kanban scenario within a single site.

Process Flow:

Kanban at PSA set to EMPTY -> EWM Replenishment WT created -> Operator picks from Reserve -> Operator moves to PSA -> WT Confirmed -> Kanban set to FULL

Configuration & Execution:

  1. Customizing (SPRO for EWM):
    • Path: SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Internal Warehouse Processes -> Replenishment Control -> Configure Replenishment Strategies
    • Define a replenishment strategy triggered by Kanban. For example, an "Advanced Planned Replenishment" strategy.
  2. Create Control Cycle:
    • Fiori App: Manage Kanban Control Cycles
    • Product: DS-GUI01
    • Replenishment Strategy: 0006 (Stock Transfer with WT generation).
    • On the "Stock Transfer" tab, you define the source EWM storage type (e.g., 001 - High Rack) and the destination (the PSA, which is also modeled as a storage type, e.g., PROD).
  3. Execute the Flow:
    • Fiori App: Kanban Board
    • Set the kanban for DS-GUI01 at the PSA to EMPTY.
    • Check the result in the Warehouse Monitor (/SCWM/MON): A new replenishment Warehouse Task has been created with status "Open."
    • Fiori App: Process Warehouse Tasks - Internal
    • An operator is assigned the task. They pick the required quantity of handlebars from the reserve bin and move them to the production supply area bin.
    • Upon confirmation of the Warehouse Task (e.g., via RF scanner), the stock is now physically and systemically in the PSA bin.
    • Check the Kanban Board: The kanban status is automatically set back to FULL, signaling to production that the parts are available.

Chapter 5: Integrated Test Plan: A Hands-On Workshop

This chapter provides a structured set of test scenarios to allow you to practice the end-to-end flows described in this guide.

5.1. Introduction to the Test Plan

Objective: To provide a practical, step-by-step validation of the core EWM and Kanban processes within the CycleCorp business context.

How to Use: Follow each step precisely. In the "Expected Result" column, we describe what should happen. You will fill in the "Actual Result" and mark the step as Pass/Fail.

5.2. Test Scenario 1: Procure-to-Pay (Component Inbound)

Goal: Test the complete inbound flow for a purchased component managed in EWM.

Step

Action / Description

Fiori App / T-Code

Input Data

Expected Result

Actual Result

1.1

Create Product Master

Manage Product Master Data

Product: DS-FRAME-01 (Frame), Type: COMP, All relevant views for EWM.

Product master is created successfully.

 

1.2

Create Business Partner

Manage Business Partner Master Data

BP Name: Carbon Frames Inc., Roles: General, Supplier (FLVN01).

Business Partner is created with a supplier role.

 

1.3

Create Purchase Order

Manage Purchase Orders

Supplier: Carbon Frames Inc., Product: DS-FRAME-01, Qty: 50, Plant: 2222, SLoc: 2223.

Purchase Order is created and saved.

 

1.4

Create Inbound Delivery

Create Inbound Deliveries

Reference the PO number from step 1.3.

Inbound Delivery is created and replicated to EWM.

 

1.5

Post Goods Receipt

Post Goods Receipt for Inbound Delivery

Find the Inbound Delivery in EWM. Post GR for 50 pcs.

Stock is now visible in the GR-ZONE. A material document and FI document are posted.

 

1.6

Process Putaway

Process Warehouse Tasks

Find the open putaway task for the inbound delivery.

System proposes a destination bin based on the putaway strategy.

 

1.7

Confirm Putaway Task

Process Warehouse Tasks

Confirm the open warehouse task in the background.

The task is confirmed. Stock moves from GR-ZONE to the final storage bin.

 

1.8

Verify Stock

Display Stock Overview

Check stock for DS-FRAME-01 in Warehouse W22.

50 pcs are visible in the specific storage bin from step 1.7.

 

5.3. Test Scenario 2: Order-to-Cash (Finished Bicycle Outbound)

Goal: Test the complete outbound flow for a finished product from the EWM warehouse.

Step

Action / Description

Fiori App / T-Code

Input Data

Expected Result

Actual Result

2.1

Create Product Master

Manage Product Master Data

Product: DS-BIKE-ROAD-01, Type: FERT (Finished Good).

Product master is created.

 

2.2

Post Initial Stock

Post Goods Movement (MIGO)

Use movement type 561 to post 10 bikes into Plant 2222, SLoc 2223. Then use EWM to put it away.

10 bikes are available in a storage bin in EWM.

 

2.3

Create Sales Order

Create Sales Orders

Customer: (Select any customer), Product: DS-BIKE-ROAD-01, Qty: 2.

Sales Order is created and saved.

 

2.4

Create Outbound Delivery

Manage Sales Orders

Create a delivery from the sales order.

Outbound Delivery is created and replicated to EWM.

 

2.5

Create Picking Tasks

Run Outbound Delivery Orders - Picking

Find the Outbound Delivery Order and create picking tasks.

A picking warehouse task is created to move 2 bikes from the storage bin to the packing area.

 

2.6

Confirm Picking Task

Process Warehouse Tasks

Confirm the picking task.

The task is confirmed. Stock moves to the packing work center.

 

2.7

Pack Handling Units

Pack Outbound Deliveries

Find the delivery, and pack the 2 bikes into a new Handling Unit (e.g., a large box).

An HU is created and assigned to the delivery.

 

2.8

Post Goods Issue

Post Goods Issue

Find the delivery and post the goods issue.

Stock is issued from the warehouse. A material document and FI document are posted.

 

2.9

Create Billing Doc

Create Billing Documents

Create an invoice referencing the sales order/delivery.

A customer invoice is generated.

 

5.4. Test Scenario 3: EWM Kanban Stock Transfer to Production

Goal: Test the automated replenishment of the production line from the main EWM warehouse using Kanban. This is based on the VELO DS - RECETTE CLIENT - 6 - KANBAN TRANSFERT WM scenario.

Step

Action / Description

Fiori App / T-Code

Input Data

Expected Result

Actual Result

3.1

Prerequisite Check

Display Stock Overview

Check stock for DS-FRAME-01 from Test Scenario 1.

At least 20 frames must be available in a reserve storage type (e.g., High Rack).

 

3.2

Create Control Cycle

Manage Kanban Control Cycles

Product: DS-FRAME-01, PSA: DS-AIR, Strategy: 0006 (EWM Transfer), No. Kanbans: 2, Qty: 10.

A classic kanban control cycle is created for EWM stock transfer.

 

3.3

Trigger Replenishment

Kanban Board

Find the control cycle. Set the status of one kanban container to EMPTY.

A replenishment warehouse task is automatically created in EWM. Kanban status is red (Empty).

 

3.4

Check Warehouse Monitor

Warehouse Monitor (/SCWM/MON)

Navigate to Outbound -> Warehouse Task.

An open warehouse task exists to move 10 frames from the reserve bin to the PSA bin.

 

3.5

Confirm WT

Process Warehouse Tasks

Find and confirm the open replenishment task.

The task is confirmed.

 

3.6

Verify Kanban Status

Kanban Board

Refresh the Kanban board view.

The kanban that was set to Empty is now FULL (green status).

 

3.7

Verify Stock Movement

Display Stock Overview

Check stock for DS-FRAME-01.

Stock in the reserve bin has decreased by 10. Stock in the PSA bin has increased by 10.

 

Appendix

A.1: Glossary of Key Terms

  • Business Partner (BP): The unified S/4HANA master data object for customers, suppliers, and other partners.
  • Control Cycle: The central master data for defining a Kanban loop.
  • EWM (Extended Warehouse Management): SAP's strategic, advanced solution for managing warehouse logistics.
  • Handling Unit (HU): A physical unit of material that includes the product and its packaging materials (e.g., a packed pallet).
  • MRP (Material Requirements Planning): The process of calculating material needs based on demand and production schedules.
  • Production Supply Area (PSA): A specific physical location on or near the production line where components are staged for consumption.
  • Storage Bin: The smallest addressable unit of space in a warehouse.
  • Storage Type: A physical or logical area in a warehouse with specific characteristics (e.g., High Rack, Cold Storage).
  • Warehouse Task (WT): An executable instruction in EWM to move a product from a source bin to a destination bin.

A.2: Fiori App and GUI Transaction Code Map

This table provides a mapping of common legacy transaction codes to their modern S/4HANA Fiori app equivalents.

Create Sales Orders

PK13N

Kanban Board

Create Control Cycle

Manage Kanban Control Cycles

Warehouse Monitor

/SCWM/MON

MIGO

Post Goods Movement

entry.title: Issue with Company Code and Purchasing Details Not Updating via API_Business_Partner through CPI
entry.content:
I‚Äôm facing an issue while using the API_Business_Partner in SAP. When I send values from an external system through CPI, the Business Partner is created successfully. However, the Company Code details and Purchasing details are not getting updated in the BP roles. When I test the same process directly in the SAP system, everything works fine. The problem occurs only when the data comes through CPI, where these specific details are not being updated.  

note: S4Hana system

Kindly suggest a solution for this urgent issue.

with regards,

Jayachitra.

entry.title: Building a CAP service with cds‚Äëmcp and Cline ‚Äî HANDS‚ÄëON SUPER BASIC GUIDE [ with screenshots ] üçå
entry.content:
Everything you‚Äôre about to read started with this brilliant SAP blog: Boost your CAP development with AI: Introducing the MCP Server for CAP. Think of it as the seed that grew into my little CAP + Cline + banana adventure. üçå

What you‚Äôll get

  • A friendly walkthrough to spin up a CAP service in VS Code
  • How to wire it to S/4HANA via a BTP Destination for local tests
  • A few real‚Äëworld bumps on Windows PATH and global installs
  • A silly ‚Äúbanana mode‚Äù at the end to prove handlers actually run üçå

Prereqs (aka ‚Äúdon‚Äôt skip me‚Äù)

  • VS Code on Windows
  • Node.js installed and on PATH
  • SAP BTP subaccount with a Destination, e.g. DEVTOBERFEST_DEST to you S4H public cloud [follow my Devtoberfest session for this]
  • Optional: Postman for poking endpoints

Step 1 ‚Äî Tools on deck

If you try to run cds init and it's not working, follow the next steps.

 

  1. CAP dev kit

npm add -g @sap/cds-dk

If global installs act shy on Windows, add this to PATH then restart VS Code:

  • C:\Users\<YourUser>\AppData\Roaming\npm

 

Step 2 ‚Äî Cline + CAP MCP server

There are a bunch of AI coding assistants out there ‚Äî GitHub Copilot, Codeium, Cursor, Tabnine ‚Äî so why bother with Cline and not Copilot or the others?

Copilot is amazing for inline coding, Cline felt like the right fit for building and testing a whole CAP service with AI in the loop.

  • Install Cline from the VS Marketplace

  • Add the CAP MCP server:
npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server

  • VS Code settings (snip):

     

Add the MCP Server configuration to your Cline:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": { "command": "cds-mcp", "args": [], "env": {} }
  }
}

Heads‚Äëup: Agents.md wasn‚Äôt supported by Cline when I tried it; check again later.

Bonus guardrails, I told Cline:

- Always use cds‚Äëmcp to look up CDS definitions before reading *.cds files.
- Always check CAP docs via cds‚Äëmcp before proposing changes.

If you check on the bottom, you can find the model version:

Cline model picks I tried:

  • anthropic/claude-sonnet-4 ‚Äî great for agentic coding, supports images/browser/prompt caching.

  • openai/gpt-5 ‚Äî state-of-the-art for long tasks, supports images/browser, no caching.

  • x-ai/grok-code-fast-1 ‚Äî free (handy after I burned credits), supports prompt caching but no images/browser.

You can see the differences between all the models, but Grok is free. After using my 10 free prompts, I switched to Grok on my daily to continue working (but not for this blog)

Step 3 ‚Äî New CAP project

cds init

The cds init command scaffolds a new CAP project.
It creates the basic folder structure (app/, db/, srv/), adds a package.json, and sets up config files so you don‚Äôt start from scratch.

In short: it‚Äôs the ‚Äúhello world‚Äù starter for CAP ‚Äî without it, you‚Äôd have to wire everything by hand.

Step 4 ‚Äî Bring in Business Partner and scaffold

After importing the EDMX file [check my video on the Devtoberfest], let's try a prompt. We want to apply this prompt to Cline:

Extend API_BUSINESS_PARTNER.

Create service.cds and service.js.

Expose only BusinessPartner with READ and CREATE. If the name contains ‚Äúbanana‚Äù, throw an error.

Result: service.cds and service.js created. MCP caching made later calls cheaper. Nice.

For this blog, I bought 2$ of credit just for testing (I already used all the free ones). Let‚Äôs see how much it will be used.

 
 

The creation seems to be working fine, and we used 82.6k credits, which is close to $1. Let‚Äôs continue the process and create the service.cds by clicking save.

The service.js file was created correctly. We also used fewer tokens because we cached the query before sending it to the MCP server.

The file also seems fine. I would not expect anything else after this, but Cline is asking me that :

Now let me check if there's a package.json file to understand the project setup and then test the implementation. and it want to read the package.json file.

I want to be more specific in this case. I have a destination defined in my btp with already access to my S4HC and exposed the business partner scenario. I would like to test locally by using this destination and my new project. Let‚Äôs then correct and add new information with my prompt.

I would like you check the package.json and prepare the project for deploy and test locally. I have a BTP destination ready and connected with name DEVTOBERFEST_DEST

 

As a money saver, I get a little annoyed paying 3 cents to ask me to run npm install, even though I know I need to do it always.
It‚Äôs fine for testing and learning purposes lol.

And another 6 cents to check and suggested me npm start. But let‚Äôs imagine we are new in this CAP world and we follow blindly Cline and the MCP.

Step 5 ‚Äî Prep for local testing with a Destination

Have a BTP Destination named DEVTOBERFEST_DEST that points to the S/4HANA Business Partner API.

After this point, I decided to add my MTA file and the destination configuration (to connect to the system) by myself. Without using any AI tool

cds add mta;
cds add xsuaa,destination,connectivity;

Step 6 ‚Äî Build, deploy, and test


Install all the package dependencies with

npm i

I decided to build and deploy by using Cline.
Something I notice differently in my usual process is the new terminal type Cline on the right.

Everything went fine, and from my postman, I can see the call


This one was the first significant milestone. I think the most challenging part was to make VSCode (for me, who I am a Business Application Code user). Let's try something more fun.

Step 7 ‚Äî Banana mode (purely for fun)

I asked (Because why not?):

When filtering by BusinessPartnerFullName for "Sebastiano Marchesini", make every field say "banana". 

This request took the MCP multiple steps and ended with $0.89 in expenses.

Not bad for banana mode, but it didn‚Äôt fully understand my request. The code set everything to ‚Äòbanana‚Äô whenever it found one in the result.

This still teaches a big truth about our development: we cannot leave everything to the AI, but we need to take care of our code and pay attention to what we produce. 
Now....
Send to prod? Absolutely not. Demo at parties? Maybe.

Token Cost Breakdown üí∞

Current Usage: ?? / 256K tokens I used in 3 sessions to prepare this blog. 

Estimated Cost: $2.45 USD

Per 1K tokens: $0.004 - $0.011

Quick fixes when things go sideways

  • Global CLI not found ‚Üí fix PATH and restart VS Code
  • npm start explodes ‚Üí run npm i in the project root
  • Destination calls fail ‚Üí ensure destination + connectivity are added and bound in BTP
  • 401/403 after deploy ‚Üí check xsuaa  and use the client id and secret only from Postman

Copy‚Äëpaste corner

# Global tools
npm add -g @sap/cds-dk
npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server

# Project
cds init
# import EDMX as needed

# BTP integration
cds add mta
cds add xsuaa,destination,connectivity
npm i

# Local run
npm start
# or
cds watch

# Build & deploy
npm run build
npm run deploy

Final questions and next steps

Did you try with other tools? How did you feel?  üëÄ

Next blog, I want to try the integration with SAPui5 MCP and Copilot. üéá

entry.title: Simulation for SAM4U Solution: Flexibility with the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption
entry.content:
When adopting SAP SAM4U, one of the biggest challenges customers face is handling role, profile, and authorization changes without disrupting production. This is where the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings real value, thanks to its simulation capabilities.

What Customers Expect from Authorization Simulation

With the simulation, customers get the ability to:

  • Log changes at the role or profile level on the system dataset.
  • Track and review roles and profiles that have been modified.
  • Revert changes at the role or profile level, either all at once or individually.
  • Modify user-to-role or user-to-profile assignments.
  • Perform mass unassignments of roles and profiles (e.g., removing SAP_ALL or SAP_NEW).
  • Identify and review changes made to users.
  • Revert user assignments back to their original state when needed.

 Pic. 01 Roles and Profiles Changes Tracking

 Pic. 02 Roles and Profiles Mass Unassignment

 Pic. 03 Changes to the Role Detailed Review

But that‚Äôs not all! The real power lies in managing simulation snapshots.

 Pic. 04 Snapshots of Simulations on the System‚Äôs Dataset Level

Why Simulation Snapshots Matter

Simulation snapshots are created at the system dataset level, allowing you to:

  • Save changes without applying them directly in production.
  • Create new consolidations from modified datasets.
  • Avoid repetitive, time-consuming rework when changes cannot be applied immediately.

Example: Working with Two Systems in Consolidation

Imagine you are analyzing two systems in a consolidation project. You make changes to roles and users in both systems. However, due to restrictions, you cannot yet apply changes in System A.

Without losing your work, you can:

  • Create a new consolidation using the dataset from System A and the modified snapshot from System B.
  • Or temporarily move the snapshot from System A into the dataset, and later reapply those changes when they are ready for production.

 Pic. 05 The Power of Management Snapshots and Datasets that are Used in Consolidation

This flexibility ensures you never have to redo your work and can manage changes efficiently.

Why Customers Prefer the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption

Customers appreciate the simulation feature because it provides:

  • System-level flexibility to manage changes.
  • Easy-to-handle snapshots that can be created, reviewed, reverted, and reused.
  • No duplication of effort, once a change is made, it is saved and can be reapplied.
  • Reliable validation, you can reload fresh production data and check if changes were successfully implemented.

If changes were tracked only at the consolidation level, fresh data from the system would overwrite them. This is why the Accelerator focuses on system snapshots, giving customers full control to experiment, validate, and roll back whenever needed.

 Pic.06 Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption Dashboard for Simulation Results Analysis

With the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, simulation becomes not just a test environment, but a strategic tool for efficient and risk-free SAM4U adoption.

entry.title: Re: SAP Enable Now: Issues with Automatic Content Visibil...
entry.content:
Hi Janice,

In theory your approach is fine to share content between two Workspaces.  If one author is seeing thing correct in a Workspace but you are not it is likely because:

1. You must download the entire Workspace into Producer.  If you have missing folders or other structural objects, sections of the content will appear in the Unsorted folder.  You can download the entire structure by opening Producer and selecting Server Workspace > Check Out All Objects and making sure that you have loaded the entire structure onto your machine
2. The other author has editing control of folders in the content structure and has not handed back that editing control.  You must be able to take editing control of folders in Producer for the structure to show correctly.  It is very, very important that authors hand back editing control of content objects and their parent folders - Finish Editing - as soon as they finish with them.  This is particularly important for the folders.  Unless you can get editing control of the folder structure the content relationships cannot be written in your version of Producer so the structure will not appear correctly

After the other authors have given back editing control of all folders, try refreshing Producer.  If the structure still does not appear correctly, take editing control of the folder where the structure is broken.  Hopefully that will allow the relationships between parent and child folders to be written and the content structure to then appear correctly.

After you take editing control of folders, don't forget to give back that control ASAP.

Regards
Shane

entry.title: Re: Regroup Receivables / Payables - exchange rate issue...
entry.content:
Hello @Shrinivas 

Thank you for your question.

Yes, what you are observing is common system behaviour in Public Cloud. Consult the following links for more details: KBA 3439952, Regroup Receivables / Payables, Schedule General Ledger Jobs, KBA 3015541

The summary is, open items that are less than a year, the regrouping program uses the original invoice posting date exchange rate.

Please note that for items older than one year, the regrouping program applies the current exchange rate at the time when you start the regrouping.

The aim is to be compliant with IFRS/GAAP requirements where receivables and payables older than a year are treated as long-term items and must be valued at the current reporting date rate rather than historical document rates.

I hope this provides the desired insight. 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Journal Entry Reverse Api
entry.content:
Hello @gulcinakcay1 

Thank you for your question.

Kindly have a look at Journal Entry, Journal Entry - Post (Synchronous)

The error indicates that the system cannot interpret your payload. Note that reversal SOAP API requires specific XML structure in public cloud. Looking at your payload, it fails because you have the wrong root elements, no namespace, no messagheader and you are referencing the wrong document. To resolve that, ensure that:

  1. The communication arrangement is active and the inbound SOAP service is enabled.
  2. Your reversal payload must include the original reference journal entry with three fields, rather than a single combined field as seen on your payload.
  3. Wrap your journal entry reversal request with the correct namespace and header.

I hope this provides the desired insight.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Deployed Objects not getting saved in SAP BODS
entry.content:
Hi,

I have run into similar behavior in the past when automating deployments with AL_ENGINE. From my experience, it‚Äôs usually not ‚Äúrandom deletion‚Äù but something related to how the repository is being targeted or cached.

A few things you can check:

  • Repository mismatch
    Make sure the repo details in your script (DB/schema, repo name) are exactly the same as the one your Designer is connected to. It‚Äôs easy to end up deploying to Repo_B while Designer is pointing at Repo_A, and then the objects look like they‚Äôve disappeared when you refresh.

  • Designer cache
    Sometimes the local object library cache causes objects to ‚Äúvanish‚Äù on refresh. Try clearing the cache (Tools ‚Üí Options ‚Üí Local Object Library) or close Designer, delete the local cache folder, then log back in and refresh.

  • Permissions / service account
    When AL_ENGINE runs under a DevOps agent account, make sure that account has proper write permissions on the repository database. Otherwise you may see objects import successfully but then disappear because the transaction didn‚Äôt commit.

Hope this helps ‚Äî let us know if checking these areas makes a difference.

Thanks,
Prasanth Thirunavukkarasu

entry.title: Re: Control the import of custom logic
entry.content:
Dear Sender,

I have read your description and there could be 2 ways to control the transport automation:

1. In your test tenant:

  • Suspend forward automation to avoid the transport get forwarded automatically: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b249d650b15e4b3d9fc2077ee921abd0/94f67439ffce48fcb40198928844d4fe.html?version=2502.500#forward-automation-settings-in-test-system
  • Turn on the Quality Assurance Approval:https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/74940689b4a54c89a04f11dc2247701a.html?version=2502.500#quality-assurance-approval

With the quality approval feature turned on, if the collection versions meet your quality requirements, you then have to approve your collection versions before forwarding them to the production system.

 

2. In your production tenant:

  • Suspend import automation to avoid the transport get imported automatically: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b249d650b15e4b3d9fc2077ee921abd0/94f67439ffce48fcb40198928844d4fe.html?version=2502.500#import-automation-settings-in-production-system

 

Thanks and Best Regards,

Bell

SAP Support

entry.title: QM-EWM integeration Configuration & Process flow - Process oriented storage control & StorageSearchS
entry.content:
Intro:
Not new. But help someone to know QM EWM Integerations
Overview:
On this blog will show you how we can use Process oriented storage control for doing quality inspection in EWM for an normal Purchase order. Here the idea is we will receive the material in Door then move it to staging area, then to Inspection workcenter in Warehouse and then to the bins in Rack of warehouse.

DR01-01 (Door) ----> GR01-01 (Staging area)-------> QINS-01 (Inspection)----------> RA01-01 (High Rack Warehouse)

Main part:
Configuration:
Define the UD code for EWM Inspection types at plant level. This is similar to QM ERP settings.
SIMG - Quality Management - Basic Settings - Maintain Settings at Plant LevelNote: Maintain PL selected set. Other wise UD code will not be shown in EWM inspection.
SIMG - Quality Management - Quality Inspection - Inspection Lot Completion - Edit Selected Sets for Usage Decisions

Generate EWM relevant QM inspection Types
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Cross Process Settings - Quality Management - Basics and Integration - Generate Inspection Object Type Versions. Click generate new version to create IOT. Then this willa appear in next config.

Activate the IOT
Here for EWM we can activate the inspection types related to EWM.
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Cross Process Settings - Quality Management - Basics and Integration - Maintain Inspection Object Types Version
Define & Activate warehouse dependent IOT
Here we can define how the inspection setup orgin to be decided. Either by rule or others.
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Cross Process Settings - Quality Management - Basics and Integration - Define and Activate Warehouse-Dependent IOTs
Also We can decide which external step from POSC to be used here.

Maintain Follow Up action for EWM
Here we can define which followup action to be performed after doing UD. Followup action will trigger warehouse task and stock movement.
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Cross Process Settings - Quality Management - Inspection Results - Maintain Follow Up Actions
We can define the actions to be performed on this actions

Define storage types:
We need to define storage types for Quality area to differentiate it from the other storage types.
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Master Data - Define Storage Types
Create one Bin for QINS storage type in /n/scwm/ls01
Specify workcenter layout
This will decide which and all fields to be displaced in /n/scwm/workst tcode.
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Master Data - Work Center - Specify Work Center Layout
Define Process Oriented Storage Control:
Here we can define the gates & process through which the material will go through from receiving till keeping it in Warehouse rack.
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Cross Process Settings - Warehouse Task - Define Process-Oriented Storage Control
POSC
Define the storage processAssign storage process steps to it.
Define Quality Work center in EWM
This is a place in warehouse where quality team will keep and inspect materials.
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Master Data - Work Center - Define Work Center
Define Bin for Quality Workcenter in EWM - /n/scwm/workst 
We need to assign a Bin to the Quality workcenter  
Define the Warehouse Process type for starting inspection with POSC
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Cross Process Settings - Warehouse Task - Define Warehouse Process Type
Determine Warehouse process type:
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Cross Process Settings - Warehouse Task - Determine Warehouse Process TypeMaintain the process type determination indicator in /n/SCWM/MAT1
Assign Default work ceter for warehouse Inspection
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Cross Process Settings - Quality Management - Inspection Results - Assign Default Work Center for Inspections
Master data with EWM inspection type
Create material master in MM01 with QM inspection type 1701Define the Inspection rule for document types - /n/scwm/qrsetup
Define the putaway strategy using the below path
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Goods Receipt Process - Strategies - Storage Type Search - Define Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway. And in same menu do the below as well
Assign Storage Types to Storage Type Search Sequence, Define Putaway Control Indicator, Specify Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway, Optimize Access Strategy for Storage Type Search: Putaway


Define the Stock Removal strategy using the below path
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Goods Issue Process - Strategies - Specify Stock Removal Rules. And in same menu do the below.
Specify Storage Type Search Sequence, Define Stock Removal Control Indicator, Determine Storage Type Search Sequence for Stock Removal, Optimize Access Strategies for Stor. Type Determination in Stock Removal
Check the WOCR has been create or not in 
SIMG - SCM EWM - EWM - Cross Process Settings - Warehouse Order - Define Creation Rules for Warehouse Orders
Create one Purchase order in ME31N with confirmation. If confirmation is not there VL31N cannot be created.Create inbound delivery in VL31N.

Pack the Material in HU or else POSC will not be copied to EWM.Do Goods receipt in EWM via /n/scwm/mon.Before GR the stock type will be F1 and after GR the stock type will be changed to Q3.
Later create warehouse task using the followup on top if its not creating in background.

In Next screen click create and save

Then go back to /n/scwm/mon and select the Warehouse request and click warehouse task to get the task created as per POSC and confirm it.On Conforming it a new task will be create and the stock will be moved from GR01-01 to QINS-01Later go to QA32 and do UDLater in UD screen click EWM inspectionLater click continue instead of closing the screen. Then give the UD and save it.In EWM an another warehouse task will be created. At last you can confirm this to move the stock from QINS-01 -----> RA01-01Conclusion:
Hope this may help someone to learn. Will add the theory and Storage type search sequence for more Idea.

entry.title: Job Scheduler with CAP Node.js OData Action Always Returns 404
entry.content:
Hello Community,

I'm trying to schedule a background task using SAP Job Scheduler in BTP to invoke an OData action exposed by my CAP Node.js service (deployed as an MTA app on Cloud Foundry). The action is defined and works as expected when triggered manually on a .http file.

However, when I configure this OData endpoint (for example:
https://<my-app-route>/odata/v4/job/logJobRun
or any similar variation identified via metadata or service root) in a Job Scheduler job, it always returns a 404 Not Found error in the job execution logs.

What I have tried:

  • Verified the CAP service and OData action are deployed and accessible interactively.

  • Used every probable endpoint path (including /odata/v4/<service-name>/<action>, with service name in different cases).

  • Searched CAP and Job Scheduler documentation and community posts for the correct pattern.

  • Ensured the Job Scheduler instance is properly bound to my service.

No matter which endpoint format I use, the Job Scheduler job log always shows a request/response status of 404, as if the OData action is simply not found by the scheduler.

Could someone please clarify:

  • What is the exact OData URL format to use for a CAP action when scheduling jobs this way?

  • Are there any special CAP annotations, deployment settings, or Job Scheduler configurations required to make OData actions callable by Job Scheduler?

  • Has anyone succeeded with this scenario and can share a working example?

Any advice, best practices, or pointers to example repos are highly appreciated!

Thanks in advance.



Below, I have given some of my code:

srv/job-service.cds

using {cuid} from '@sap/cds/common';

service JobService {

    action logJobRun() returns String;

}


srv/job-service.js

const cds = require('@sap/cds');

module.exports = cds.service.impl(async function () {

  // In-memory array to store job run logs

  let jobRunLogs = [];

  this.on('logJobRun', async (req) => {

    try {

      const timestamp = new Date().toISOString();

      const message = `Job triggered at ${timestamp}`;

      // Log Job Scheduler headers (helpful for debugging)

      if (req.headers) {

        console.log(`[JOB SCHEDULER POC] Job ID: ${req.headers['x-sap-job-id'] || 'N/A'}`);

        console.log(`[JOB SCHEDULER POC] Job Run ID: ${req.headers['x-sap-job-run-id'] || 'N/A'}`);

        console.log(`[JOB SCHEDULER POC] Schedule ID: ${req.headers['x-sap-job-schedule-id'] || 'N/A'}`);

      }

      // Add to in-memory array

      jobRunLogs.push({

        timestamp: timestamp,

        message: message,

        runCount: jobRunLogs.length + 1,

        jobId: req.headers?.['x-sap-job-id'] || null,

        runId: req.headers?.['x-sap-job-run-id'] || null

      });

      // Log to console

      console.log(`[JOB SCHEDULER POC] ${message}`);

      console.log(`[JOB SCHEDULER POC] Total job runs: ${jobRunLogs.length}`);

      // Return success message (Job Scheduler expects this)

      return `Job executed successfully at ${timestamp}. Total runs: ${jobRunLogs.length}`;

    } catch (error) {

      console.error('[JOB SCHEDULER POC] Error during job execution:', error);

      throw error; // This will return HTTP 500 to Job Scheduler

    }

  });

});

test/test.http

### Test Job Action  

POST http://localhost:4004/odata/v4/job/logJobRun

Content-Type: application/json

{}

{

  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "A simple CAP project.",
  "repository": "<Add your repository here>",

  },

  },

entry.title: Blueprints for Success: Landscape setup recommendations for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

In today‚Äôs fast-changing times, integration is not just a technical requirement but a business imperative. Organizations worldwide run on a combination of on-premises systems, cloud applications, and home-grown or partner platforms, which makes realizing efficient End-to-End (E2E) business processes that much more challenging! Integration plays a crucial role in driving digital transformation and agile innovation by enabling seamless connectivity between various systems and applications within an organization‚Äôs IT landscape.

SAP Integration Suite offers an intelligent, future-proof, scalable, AI-driven Integration Platform-as-a-Service (iPaaS) that simplifies enterprise-wide connectivity to any application or business partner, enables real-time data exchange, and supports modern integration patterns ‚Äî empowering customers on their journey towards an agile SAP Business Suite.

Every enterprise begins its integration journey with the right intentions: connecting systems, enabling business process automation, and improving agility, among others. However, without a well-defined integration setup strategy, the journey can quickly spiral into chaos.

Integration Blueprints and why they matter

Having the right integration setup is crucial for ensuring efficiency, reliability, security compliance, and resilience. A well-structured integration landscape provides the flexibility required to adapt business processes and adopt new technologies like Artificial Intelligence, forming the foundation for data-driven decision-making and business innovation.

In the context of SAP Integration Suite, an integration blueprint is a recommended landscape design that defines how integration tenants are provisioned, distributed, and interconnected to deliver enterprise-wide integration. It establishes the guardrails for security, lifecycle management, and governance across the landscape. By mapping out business processes and compliance requirements in advance, the blueprint ensures that integration projects can scale reliably while staying aligned with business goals and IT strategy.

In this blog, let‚Äôs explore how your integration blueprints can evolve from modest beginnings towards a mature, enterprise-grade landscape with SAP Integration Suite.

Evolution of Integration Blueprints

For the sake of illustration, we will follow the evolutionary timeline of SAP Integration Suite blueprints, with a fictional company, BestRun Corporation.

BestRun Corporation is a multinational enterprise operating across industries like manufacturing, retail, and financial services. Its SAP landscape is a mix of SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, and several custom-built applications spread across regions.

Like many organizations we work with, BestRun‚Äôs integration journey didn‚Äôt start with a big bang; it evolved.

Stage 1: The Primitive Era ‚Äì Experimentation

In the early days, BestRun Financial Services unit began with a single SAP Integration Suite tenant for a proof-of-concept. During the pilot phase, development, testing, and production all happened in the same tenant.

Although this worked well for experimentation and helped in keeping service costs low, when a bug in a test integration flow disrupted real purchase orders, they soon realized that the setup lacked critical capabilities to run their business, like workload isolation. Additionally, the setup was not meeting the BestRun Corporation company-wide compliance and audit requirements.

Pros:

  • Quick and cost-effective option to get started.
  • Simple setup, minimal management overhead.
  • Good for PoC/Pilots or experimentation.

Cons:

  • No isolation of workloads; high risk of disruptions.
  • No governance, poor compliance, and auditability.
  • Not fit for enterprise businesses.

BestRun worked with SAP to understand that once a project gets into active development or productive phase, it is strongly recommended to establish the typical enterprise setup of SAP Integration Suite, with a Multitenant landscape model to ensure separation of concerns and smooth operations.

Stage 2: The Growth Era ‚Äì Staged Development blueprint

Realizing the risks, the BestRun Financial Services team adopted a staged development setup with multiple tenants. This landscape setup follows a structured progression of controlled tenants to ensure reliable delivery of integrations, enforcing strong governance and minimal risk of impacting business operations.

A staged development setup typically consists of a 3-stage landscape, 

  • Development (Dev) tenant - where integration developers build and configure integrations
  • Testing/Quality Assurance (Test/QA) tenant - where functional validation, regression testing, and user acceptance are conducted, ensuring quality compliance, and
  • Production (Prod) tenant ‚Äì where end users consume integrations in business-critical processes, shielded from disruptions

If you only use pre-packaged integration content, then the Test/QA tenant can be used to preview and validate the content before deploying to the Prod tenant. For custom integration content development, the integration is developed in the Dev, validated in QA, and pushed to Prod.

Sometimes, additional stages like Pre-Production (Pre-Prod), Canary, and/or Staging are introduced. The Pre-prod mirrors the production environment and can be used for backups, regression testing, and delayed software updates. Canary tenants can be used for controlled roll-outs of updates/releases to select consumers for early feedback. A Staging tenant can be set up for performance testing or a production-like validation.

Additionally, the BestRun Financial Services team wanted to run a few business-critical scenarios, which consume resources in an isolated SAP Integration Suite tenant, to ensure there are no disruptions due to resource competition. This is currently achieved using a manual Tenant-Split process, where a hand-picked integrations are moved to a dedicated tenant. However, there are investments to support such requirements seamlessly, soon.  

Staged development setup with LoBs

Usually, a staged development setup for SAP Integration Suite is tightly coupled and aligned with a staged LoB application landscape like the SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3SL setup, where each S/4HANA Cloud tenant (DEV/QAS/PRD) is connected to a corresponding SAP Integration Suite tenant (Dev/QA/Prod) to ensure environment parity.

A similar landscape setup can also be used by SAP NetWeaver Process Integration / Process Orchestration (PI/PO) customers who typically use a 3 PI/PO system landscape on-premises. While migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite, customers need to move from a system-centric to a tenant-centric model; however, the principle remains the same.

Note that in the case of SAP PI/PO, where infrastructure is fully managed by customers, there may be instances where PI/PO systems have been set up with substantial resources. Since SAP Integration Suite operates as a cloud-based service, careful tenant sizing is recommended rather than employing a direct 1:1 mapping between systems and tenants.

Pros:

  • Clear separation of concerns and environments (Dev, Test, Prod).
  • Reduced production risk from developments, experiments.
  • Aligns with standard SAP application landscapes (e.g., S/4HANA 3SL).
  • Establishes a foundation for enterprise governance.

Cons:

  • Maybe limited to large organizations with multiple BUs or regions.
  • Requires process discipline across teams, which takes time.

In this blueprint, it will be important for BestRun to invest in a robust framework of versioned artifacts, aligned DevOps pipelines, synchronized transport management, and a strict governance setup to manage APIs & endpoints in each stage, for seamless business operations.

Stage 3: The Scale Era ‚Äì Business Entity Blueprint

With the Financial Services team recognizing business value with SAP Integration Suite, BestRun decided to expand the rollout of SAP Integration Suite to further business units like Retail, Manufacturing, etc.

Today, BestRun Corporation runs a federated IT environment, establishing logical or physical separation of IT systems within each business unit (BU) or entity, thereby enhancing compliance alignment and supporting a greater degree of autonomy. Typically, this federated approach is supported by an independent IT team dedicated to each respective business unit or entity. From an Integration perspective, the respective BU IT team will manage and maintain the corresponding SAP Integration Suite setup as well.

In such cases, it is widely regarded as best practice to provision a dedicated Integration Suite staged landscape (at least Dev -> Test -> Prod) for every business unit or entity. This arrangement enables BU IT teams to develop, test, run, and manage integrations tailored to their specific compliance obligations or organizational policies. Example:

  • Retail IT teams can focus on point-of-sale and customer loyalty integrations.
  • Manufacturing IT teams can optimize supply chain processes.
  • Finance IT teams focus on compliance-heavy reporting integrations and so on.

Pros:

  • Increase autonomy for each business unit (BU).
  • Tailored compliance alignment per BU.
  • Independent BU IT teams innovate at their own pace.
  • Reduces bottlenecks and dependency on centralized IT.

 Cons:

  • Requires investments into additional tenants.
  • Strong governance is necessary to avoid duplication of efforts and the risk of siloed BU integrations.

Stage 4: The Global Era ‚Äì Regional Blueprint

With operations in Europe, the US, and APJ, BestRun Corporation faced new challenges to meet GDPR and local banking laws, which required regional data residency, establishing distributed resilience for business continuity, and meeting LoB application performance requirements.

For multinational companies, like BestRun, with globally distributed business entities and subsidiaries, it may be necessary to deploy IT systems, including Integration Suite tenants, across multiple regions to address

  • Region-specific data residency requirements, such as GDPR, HIPAA, and local banking regulations
  • Latency requirements with Line-of-Business applications operating worldwide
  • Business continuity objectives.

This approach will enable business entities within a region to maintain a comprehensive regional autonomy, ensuring data residency and adherence to region- and industry-specific compliance requirements. IT teams are advised to establish a staged development setup in each region to facilitate effective and coordinated integration management.

While this blueprint is common in enterprises where IT responsibilities are decentralized by Business Units, it still requires strong central governance to ensure consistency and re-use across company entities.

Companies may choose a Hybrid model, which combines global oversight with support for local compliance and autonomy. For SAP Integration Suite, this approach may involve using global tenants to manage enterprise-wide or cross-BU integrations, while local BU tenants address regional BU-specific integrations. A strong governance model and organizational structure are necessary to support an efficient Hybrid tenant model. SAP Integration Suite includes the Edge Integration Cell (EIC) runtime, which addresses edge or compliance scenarios and can connect to a local BU tenant.

Pros:

  • Meet regional compliance & data residency requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, local banking laws).
  • Improve performance and reduce latency for in-region integrations
  • Enhance resilience with distributed landscapes.

Cons:

  • Requires a strong balance between global and regional governance
  • Requires centralized monitoring across regions.
  • Costs grow with each regional deployment.

While this blueprint is tailored to global enterprises, companies are advised to evaluate the need for such a setup in all regions based on regional requirements.

Stage 5: The Mature Era ‚Äì Governed Multi-Tenant Strategy

Over time, BestRun Corporation achieved Integration setup maturity, with a reliable, enterprise-wide blueprint that brings the best of both worlds together. The model consists of global SAP Integration Suite tenants designed for shared enterprise integrations, regional SAP Integration Suite tenants that address local regulations and optimize latency, and business unit (BU) tenants tailored for customized business entity-relevant processes.

The goal is not to blindly add ‚Äòmore tenants‚Äô, but move to a smarter, governed model that balances autonomy, compliance, and efficiency. To ensure effective management of this setup, robust governance measures have been implemented. These include automated transport pipelines, centralized monitoring using SAP Cloud ALM, consistent security and identity policies, and a documented tenant strategy to ensure coordination across IT teams in the organization.

BestRun also established an Integration Center of Excellence (CoE) to ensure its Integration strategy was not only technically sound but also organizationally sustainable. Acting as both a governance body and innovation driver, the CoE defines the integration blueprints, enforces governance and security standards, creates reusable integration assets, enables regional IT teams through training & best practices, and pilots emerging capabilities like AI-driven integration.

This balance of global oversight with local autonomy positioned SAP Integration Suite as a strategic enabler of business agility and innovation.

Conclusion

Integration setup is not a one-size-fits-all decision. BestRun Corporation‚Äôs story shows that SAP Integration Suite blueprints tend to evolve - from a single-tenant experiment to a governed, multi-tenant, multi-region landscape, as the organization evolves to transform, scale, and globalize.

Ask yourself, which integration blueprint best shows your current state, and which one matches organizational needs:

  • Are you still experimenting in a single tenant?
  • Have you moved into a staged development setup?
  • Are you operating a mature, governed multi-tenant landscape with global reach?

Wherever you are in this evolution, the key is to keep moving forward till you reach the target setup. Every step towards structured tenant management strengthens your ability to deliver reliable, intelligent, and future-proof integration.

With SAP Integration Suite and well-defined integration blueprints, enterprises can shape landscapes that not only support today‚Äôs business processes but also empower tomorrow‚Äôs innovations.
